speaker: D
text: Absolutely. It's a great question. The world of web three consists of smart contracts, and one thing that distinguishes them is that there is no company behind the smart contract. And so it's just basically a set of code, and it will execute so long as the parameters are met. And the parameters could be, I want to take out a giant loan or my loan needs to be liquidated. And since there's no kind of third party that's going to make any judgment calls on that, the data that comes in to determine what actions are taken is powermen. And so they refer to this as the oracle problem. And I can give you a very simple example that can kind of make this a little bit more clear. So, Margo, let's say that we're going to write a smart contract that is going to bet on the outcome of a football game. The Patriots first say the jets, and we lock up a certain amount of ETh in a smart contract. Now, we know that one of us is going to walk out with the Ethereum, and what we don't know and what the blockchain doesn't know is who actually won the game. So if I am betting that the Pats lose and the jets win, no matter what happens, I'm going to be incentivized to say, that's the result and vice versa for you. So that kind of underscores the fact that you need to have some trustworthy resource to be able to provide that information on a consistent basis. And so they refer to this as the oracle problem. And this is what Oracle networks do, is they provide a trustworthy way to get data onto smart contracts or onto the blockchain to be used in the resolution of smart contracts.

speaker: C
text: That makes sense. That makes sense. But in defi, there are no middlemen. So smart contracts do this, and therefore, data oracles. The smart contract needs the information to be able to say, okay, who won the game? And so the data oracles, they go and they collect, fetch this data, and they bring it to the smart contract, and they say, okay, so the Patriots won, which means Mike wons the bet, and Mike won the bet, and we're going to send the payoff to Mike. Is that kind of a good way of summing it up in a nutshell.

speaker: D
text: Yeah, absolutely. Like, if we were to not use a casino, but the two of us bet on this sports game, we would just go to ESPN. Like, okay, look, it's quite clear that the Pats won, and therefore I won the bet. And so that's sort of what I think the model within the chainlink system is. So they have nodes which go out and fetch this data from basically the Internet or web two, and they go to websites like Coingecko and Coinmarketcap or Finance. And they'll sometimes have dozens of these nodes going out and grabbing the data, but it'll come from just a handful of sources. And so then they'll replay that on chain. And there are certain limitations with that, and some of them are around the fact that you can't update as you can't update any faster than those websites update, or you can include additional information that those websites don't have. There's also a data licensing issue that's like a big deal, especially if you start getting into the land of traditional assets. So in the world of us equities, there is a tremendous amount of revenue that's paid just to be able to get access to real time data to say, Apple or Tesla. And I'm talking about the realms of like three to $5 billion a year. And so when you were, if you were to try and take that data directly from the Internet, from Yahoo Finance, you'd find yourselves in the middle of a big lawsuit. So the pith model is very different. The pith model is set up in such a way where the data providers will provide data directly on chain without the use of this middleman or this node that goes and fetches it. It's been very successful in attracting lots of high quality data providers. Today, each data provider has been disclosed.

speaker: D
text: Yeah, Mark, it's a great point, because we chose Solana because it was the fastest block time and the lowest cost of a major layer one. We wanted to be cross chain from the start. We have now actually moved off to an application specific version of Solana. It's called Pithnet, and that feeds to wormhole. And then basically, anyone that is on a chain that's connected to wormhole is able to take a pith message and deploy it on those chains locally. So we went live first with the BNB chain. Venus was our launch partner, and there's a few others that have joined. And then Aptos has just launched, and we've got ten launch partners on the Aptos ecosystem. We think that the speeds that Solana is capable of will be similar to the speeds that Aptos will be capable of. It comes down to sort of pushing up against the rules of physics. So Pithnet is a very lightweight version of Solana's technology. It doesn't compete with the things that have made Solana become congested. So, like, Solana has really been made to do, like, defi at Nasdaq speeds, I guess, is the way that Anatolia said it. But then they all of a sudden became super popular and successful for NFT projects, and they hadn't anticipated that. And so when they get clogged and sometimes the network is not running, it's usually because someone has done some giant NFT. So by being over on Pithnet, we are now no longer exposed to that congestion. So we think that we can probably be just as fast and we've convinced the users of pith on other chains that that will be the case. And, you know, we think that there's room for both Solana and Naptos to kind of grow and thrive and to find their. Their niches.
